title-group.article-title: Chromosome painting reveals genomic structure of three polyploid species of Ipomoea

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Cultivated sweetpotato (Ipomoea batatas (L.) Lam.) from the family Convolvulaceae is a hexaploid species with 2n = 6x = 90, and has been controversial regarding its nature as an autopolyploid arising within a species or allopolyploid forming between species. Here, we developed oligonucleotide-based painting probes for two chromosomes of I.nil, a model diploid Ipomoea species. Using these probes, we revealed pairing behavior of homoeologous chromosomes in I. batatas and its two possible polyploid ancestral species, tetraploid I. tabascana (2n = 4x = 60) and hexaploid I. trifida (2n = 6x = 90). Chromosome painting analysis revealed a high percentage of quadrivalent formation in zygotene-pachytene cells of I. tabascana, which supported that I. tabascana was an autotetraploid likely derived by doubling of structurally similar and homologous genomes rather than a hybrid between I. batatas and I. trifida (2x). The high frequency of hexavalent/bivalent and tetravalent pairing was observed in I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas. However, the percentage of hexavalent pairing in I. trifida (6x) was far higher than that in I. batatas. Thus, present results tended to support that I. trifida (6x) was an autohexaploid, while I. batatas was more likely to be a segmental allohexaploid.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cultivated sweetpotato (Ipomoea batatas (L.) Lam) is the most important food and vegetable crop in the genus Ipomoea (Convolvulaceae). Because of its great economic importance, efforts are underway in various parts of the world to improve the crop through breeding programs. A more effective genetic improvement of sweetpotato depends on better understanding of its genome structure. However, sweetpotato is a hexaploid species with complex genome structure (2n = 6x = 90), and its genome nature has not yet been defined and two opposite inferences (auto- vs. allohexaploid) were proposed based on various studies (reviewed by Gao et al. 2020). The autopolyploid scenario assumed that I. trifida (H. B. K.) Don. formed a complex with ploidy levels ranging from diploid to hexaploid, and I. trifida (6x) was direct ancestor of domesticated sweetpotato (Nishiyama 1959, 1971; Shiotani and Kawase 1989; Muñoz-Rodríguez et al. 2018). In contrast, some studies favored an allohexaploid origin and demonstrated that I. trifida was not the sole parental donor of sweetpotato, and tetraploid I. tabascana and some other relatives may also have involved in the origin of sweetpotato (Jarret and Austin 1994; Rajapakse et al. 2004; Srisuwan et al. 2006; Gao et al. 2011).

Chromosomal karyotype and pairing data are commonly used to assess the genomic structure of polyploid species (Solís Neffa and Fernández 2002; He et al. 2018; Qu et al. 2021). Karyotype analysis relies on accurate and consistent chromosome identification. However, distinguishing sweetpotato's chromosomes at somatic cells proved unrewarding due to the similarity in chromosome size and morphology (Sharma and Datta 1958; Sun et al. 2019). Although the differentiated pachytene chromosomes with their readily recognizable centromere and distinctive chromomere pattern are more easily distinguished from each other than mitotic metaphase chromosomes, the entire pachytene chromosome complement could not be completely analyzed from one meiotic cell of sweetpotato (Magoon et al. 1970). For chromosome pairing analysis, the predominantly bivalent synapsis of chromosomes at metaphase I has been one of the main criteria in postulating an allohexaploid origin of sweetpotato (Ting et al. 1957; Jones 1965) since multivalents are expected in autopolyploids. However, this chromosome pairing-based assessment can be problematic because autopolyploids can evolve into a stable state in which the homologous chromosomes can pair predominately as bivalents rather than multivalents (Santos et al. 2003; Wu et al. 2014; Bomblies et al. 2016). Moreover, it is technically challenging to monitor the pairing of specific chromosomes and unambiguously identify various multivalent pairing configurations at different stages of meiosis in polyploid species. These deficiencies have led to opposite views (auto- vs. allohexaploid) being proposed for the genome structure of sweetpotato based on cytological studies (Ting et al. 1957; Jones 1965; Magoon et al. 1970; Shiotani and Kawase 1989; Oracion et al. 1990).

Oligo-based chromosome painting probes have recently been successfully used to identify individual chromosomes and monitor pairing of homologous or homeologous chromosomes at different meiosis stages( Han et al. 2015; He et al. 2018; Albert et al. 2019; Braz et al. ). Moreover, chromosome-specific oligo painting probes designed from one species can be used in other plants related to the target species (reviewed by Jiang 2019 ). For example, the first oligo probes developed from cucumber( Cucumis sativus) produced excellent signals on chromosomes of other Cucumis species that diverged from cucumber up to 12 million years ago (Mya)( Han et al. ). Similarly, oligo probes designed from potato( Solanum tuberosum) showed FISH signals on chromosomes of other Solanum species that diverged from potato approximately 5–8 Mya( Braz et al. ). The oligo probes designed from Populus trichocarpa showed chromosome-specific signals on chromosomes of five different Populus species that diverged for nearly 14 Mya( Xin et al. ). Oligo painting probes can be designed for any plant species with a sequenced genome. Although the whole-genome sequence of sweetpotato is available, DNA pseudomolecules have not been anchored to individual chromosomes( Yang et al. ), which prevents the design of chromosome-specific oligo probes in sweetpotato. By contrast, complete genome sequence was reported and the assembled sequences have been anchored to individual chromosomes in I. nil, a model diploid species in Ipomoea( Hoshino et al. 2016 ), which diverged from sweetpotato ∼3.6 Mya( Wu et al. 2018; Muñoz-Rodríguez et al. 2018 ). This provides opportunity for developing oligo probes for cross-species painting analysis among Ipomoea species. In the present study, we developed whole-chromosome specific oligo probes for I. nil chromosomes 7 and 15, which are the shortest two chromosomes( Chen et al. ). These probes allowed us to reveal the genomic structure and the interspecific relationship between sweetpotato and its two possible polyploid ancestral species I. tabascana and I. trifida (6x) by detailed analysis of mitotic chromosomal morphology and meiotic chromosome pairing behavior.

sec.title: Plant materials and chromosome preparation
sec.p: I. tabascana (2n = 4x = 60, PI 518479) was obtained from the National Plant Germplasm System (Gainesville, Florida, United States). The I. trifida hexaploid strain K123 (2n=6x=90) and randomly selected four sweetpotato cultivars (I. batatas “Zi 8”, “Quanru 16”, “Ziyun 2”, and “Neiyuzi 2”) were obtained from the Xuzhou sweetpotato Research Centre (China). I. nil was obtained from the Jiangsu Jiayuan Seed Company of Ginkgo and Forest in our previous study (Chen et al. 2020). Chromosome preparation was performed according to Sun et al. (2013). In brief, young roots were harvested from germinated seeds or growing plants and pretreated in 2 mM 8-hydroxyquinoline at room temperature for 2 h, then fixed in 3:1 ethanol/glacial acetic acid (v/v) for 2 h and stored in 70% ethanol at −20 °C until use. Root tips were washed for 30 min with distilled water and digested in 2% cellulase Onozuka R-10 (Yakult Pharmaceutical, Tokyo) and 1% pectolyase Y-23 (ICN) at 37 °C for 2 h. The digested root tips were macerated on glass slides in 50% acetic acid with fine-pointed forceps and then “flame-dried” over an alcohol flame. For meiotic chromosome preparation, young flower buds were harvested and fixed in 3:1 ethanol/glacial acetic acid (v/v) at room temperature for at least 24 h. One anther from each flower bud was dissected to examine the developmental stage of pollen mother cells. The remaining anthers from the same flower bud were then used for slide preparation. Anthers at proper meiotic stages were washed for 30 min with distilled water and digested in the enzyme mixture for 3 h. Meiotic slides were also prepared by “flame dried” methods.

sec.title: 45S rDNA probe and oligo probes
sec.p: Preparation of 45S rDNA oligo probes followed Han et al. (2018). Three 45S rDNA oligo sequences derived from the coding region of 5.8S, 18S and 25S rRNA from A. thaliana, respectively, were synthesized and at 5’-end with 6-carboxytetramethylrhodamine (TAMRA) and mixed together as 45S rDNA probe.

Four oligo libraries were designed for I. nil chromosomes 7 (7-1 and 7-2) and 15 (15-1 and 15-2) (Table S1). Each library contained oligos that were specific to half of each chromosome, which possessed densities of 1.2–3.0 (7-1), 2.2–3.6 (7-2), 2.3–3.5 (15-1), and 2.2–3.4 (15-2) oligos per kilobase, respectively. The design, amplification, and labeling of oligo libraries followed our published procedure( Han et al. ). Briefly, the repetitive sequences from each selected scaffolds (Table S1) were filtered and remaining sequences were then divided into oligos (48 nt) in a step size of 5 nt. Each oligo was aligned to the reference genome of I. nil( Hoshino et al., 2016) to filter out those with duplicates in the genome (>75% similarity over all 48 nt). Oligos with dTm>10 (dTm=Tm –hairpin Tm) were kept to build a probe database. To ensure that the painting probes generated uniform signals on the chromosomes, the oligos were selected to be uniformly distributed on whole chromosomes. Each oligo contained 48 bp of genomic sequence, a 5′ F primer, which included the T7 RNA polymerase promoter sequence, and a 3′ R primer. The oligos were synthesized by Arbor Biosciences (Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA).

sec.title: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)
sec.p: The FISH procedure applied to both mitotic and meiotic chromosomes was performed according to Jiang et al. (1995) with slight modifications. About 100 ng of each labeled probe was used for each slide in a hybridization mixture with 50% (v/v) formamide, 10% (w/v) dextran , and 2 × SSC. Slide-bound chromosomal DNA was denatured in a solution of 70% formamide in 2 × SSC for 1.5 min at 80 °C and dehydrated in a −20 °C ethanol series (70%, 90%, and 100% ethanol; 5 min each). Twenty microliters of hybridization mixture was applied to each slide and sealed under a coverslip with rubber cement. After overnight incubation at 37 °C, the coverslips were removed and the slides were washed at room temperature in 2 × SSC for 5 min, at 42 °C in 2 × SSC for 10 min, at room temperature in 2 × SSC for 5 min, and at room temperature in l × PBS (phosphate-buffered saline) for 5 min. Biotin-labeled probes (7-1 and 15-1) were detected using Alexa Fluor 488 streptavidin (Invitrogen), and digoxigenin-labeled probes (7-2 and 15-2) were detected using rhodamine (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, Indiana). The chromosomes were counterstained with 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) in a VectaShield antifade solution (Vector Laboratories). FISH images were captured digitally using a Leica DM6000 B fully automated upright microscope system. Gray-scale images were captured for each color channel and then merged, and final image adjustments were performed with Adobe Photoshop 6.0 using only cropping and functions affecting the whole image equally. Two or three mitotic slides and six to eight meiotic slides were hybridized and analyzed for each probe and species or combination.

sec.title: Chromosome painting in I. nil
sec.p: Probe libraries 7-1 and 7-2 were simultaneously hybridized to somatic metaphase cells of I. nil (Fig. 1a1). Even though there were some background signals on other chromosomes (Figs. 1a2–1a3), the two probes generated bright and specific FISH signals on only a single pair of chromosomes (Fig. 1a1). Similarly, probe libraries 15-1 and 15-2 also generated specific FISH signals on only a single pair of chromosomes (Figs. 1b1–1b3).

sec.title: Chromosome painting in tetraploid I. tabascana
sec.p: In tetraploid I. tabascana, all four probes for I. nil chromosome 7 (7-1 and 7-2) and 15 (15-1 and 15-2) produced chromosome-specific FISH signals on four somatic metaphase chromosomes( Figs. 2a – 2b ). Four chromosomes painted by 7-1 and 7-2 probes were almost same in chromosome size and morphology( Fig. 2a ), while two chromosomes were longer among four chromosomes painted by 15-1 and 15-2 probes( Fig. 2b ). FISH analysis with 45S rDNA and 15-1 probes showed that two longer chromosomes had stronger 45S rDNA signals than two shorter chromosomes( Fig. 2c ), and satellites and secondary constrictions could clearly be identified on the short arms of two longer chromosomes( Fig. 2c, indicated by arrows).

sec.p: We then examined the pairing configurations of homologous chromosomes painted by 15-1 and 15-2 probes at meiotic prophase I and metaphase I cells. The four homologous chromosomes paired as a quadrivalent in 81.7% (49/60) of the cells at the zygotene–pachytene stage of meiosis (Table 1; Fig. 2d). Two independent bivalents were observed in the remaining 18.3% (11/60) of the cells (Table 1; Fig. 2e). By contrast, cells with one quadrivalent were reduced to 19.4% (7/36) (Table 1; Fig. 2g), while cells with two bivalents were increased to 80.6% (29/36) (Table 1; Fig. 2f) at metaphase I of meiosis.

sec.title: Chromosome painting in mitotic cells from I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas
sec.p: The probes 7-1 and 7-2 hybridized to six chromosomes in I. trifida (6x) and all cultivars of I. batatas examined, and six chromosomes were similar in chromosome size and morphology (Figs. 3a1–3e1). While probes 15-1 and 15-2 hybridized to five chromosomes in I. trifida (6x) (Fig. 3a2), six chromosomes in I. batatas “Zi 8” (Fig. 3b2), “Quanru 16” (Fig. 3c2) and “Ziyun 2” (Fig. 3d2), and seven chromosomes in “Neiyuzi 2” (Fig. 3e2), respectively. Although only five chromosomes were painted by probes 15-1 and 15-2, I. trifida (6x) has 90 chromosomes, which is consistent with previous report (Nishiyama et al. 1961). Three I. batatas cultivars have the expected chromosome number of 2n=90, while “Neiyuzi 2” has 92 chromosomes (Fig. 3e2). The chromosomes painted by 15-1 and 15-2 also showed the difference of chromosome length, and one big heterochromatic knob, which was intensively stained by DAPI, was observed on one chromosome in I. batatas “Quanru 16”, “Ziyun 2”, and “Neiyuzi 2” (Figs. 3c2–3e2, indicated by arrowheads). FISH analysis with 45S rDNA and 15-1 probes showed that the difference of chromosome length was mainly due to the presence or absence of satellite and heterochromatic knob (Figs. 3a3–3e3). The satellites showing strong 45S rDNA signals were observed on two chromosomes in I. trifida (6x), and three chromosomes in I. batatas “Ziyun 2” and “Neiyuzi 2” (Figs. 3a3, 3d3–3e3, indicated by arrows).

sec.title: Chromosome painting in meiotic cells from I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas
sec.p: In I. trifida (6x), the six chromosomes painted by 7-1 and 7-2 probes paired as a hexavalent in 77.3% (17/22) of the zygotene–pachytene cells at different configuration (Table 2; Fig. 4a). In a few cells, all six chromosomes were found to align along much of the chromosome lengths (Fig. 4b). One bivalent and one quadrivalent were observed in the remaining 5 (22.7%) cells (Table 2; Fig. 4c). By contrast, cells with one hexavalent were reduced to 15.7% (13/83) (Table 2; Fig. 4f), while cells with one bivalent and one quadrivalent were increased to 45.8% (38/83) (Table 2; Fig. 4d), and three bivalents were observed in 38.5% (32/83) of the cells (Table 2; Fig. 4e) at metaphase I.

sec.p: The five chromosomes painted by 15-1 and 15-2 probes paired as one pentavalent in 86% (18/21) of the zygotene–pachytene cells (Fig. S1a). One bivalent and one trivalent were observed in the remaining 3 (14%) cells (Fig. S1b). At metaphase I, five homologous chromosomes paired as two bivalents and one univalent in approximately 45% (50/110) of the cells (Fig. S1c), one bivalent and one trivalent in 32% (35/110) of the cells (Fig. S1d), one pentavalent in 16% (18/110) of the cells (Fig. S1e), and one quadrivalent and one univalent in the remaining 7 (6%) cells (Fig. S1f).

For the I. batatas “Zi 8”, in a total of 112 zygotene–pachytene cells painted by 15-1 and 15-2 probes, six homologous chromosomes paired as a hexavalent in 63 (56.3%) cells (Table 2; Fig. 5a), one bivalent and one quadrivalent in 41 (36.6%) cells (Table 2; Fig. 5b), and three independent bivalents in the remaining 8 (7.1%) cells (Table 2; Fig. 5c). By contrast, cells with one hexavalent were reduced to 2.9% (1/35) (Table 2; Fig. 5f), while cells with three independent bivalents were increased to 57.1% (20/35) (Table 2; Fig. 5d), and one bivalent and one quadrivalent were observed in the remaining 11 (31.4%) cells (Table 2; Fig. 5e) at metaphase I. In addition, six homologous chromosomes paired as one univalent, one bivalent and one trivalent in two cells (Fig. S2a), and two univalents and two bivalents were observed in one cell (Fig. S2b).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Polyploid species can be categorized into autopolyploids and allopolyploids. Autopolyploids are traditionally considered to arise within a single species by duplication of a genome( Stebbins ), or doubling of structurally similar, homologous genomes (AAAA), whereas allopolyploids arise via interspecific hybridization and subsequent doubling of nonhomologous (i.e., homoeologous) genomes (AABB)( Parisod et al. 2010 ). Yet a strict boundary between these two categories is not always evident, such that an intermediate form called “segmental allopolyploids” is proposed in order to denote the doubling of only partly differentiated genomes (AAA“A”)( Stebbins 1947 ). Even so, the distinctions between auto- and allo-polyploids have been challenging and controversial. The same polyploid taxon can be considered to an autopolyploid or an allopolyploid under a different criterion( De Queiroz 2007; Parisod et al. 2010; Doyle and Sherman-Broyles 2017 ).

I. tabascana is a recently discovered species, and its origin and polyploidy type is unclear (Austin and De La Puente 1991). Several studies showed that I. tabascana was closely related to I. batatas (Jarret and Austin 1994; Rajapakse et al. 2004; Srisuwan et al. 2006), and postulated I. tabascana to be either a hybrid between I. batatas and I. trifida (2x) (Srisuwan et al. 2006; Muñoz-Rodríguez et al. 2018) or likely progenitor of I. batatas (Gao et al. 2011; Sun et al. 2019). The present meiotic chromosome pairing analysis revealed a high percentage (82%) of quadrivalent formation in zygotene-pachytene cells of I. tabascana, indicating close homology among four chromosomes. The percentage is very close to the theoretically and practically predicted quadrivalent frequencies at meiotic pachytene cells in autotetraploids such as Hordeum vulgare, Oenothera affinis and Solanum tuberosum (Sved 1966; Jackson and Casey 1982; He et al. 2018). In addition, the four homologous chromosomes painted by 15-1 and 15-2 probes could be partitioned into two different pairs based on the presence or absence of satellites and secondary constrictions. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that I. tabascana is an autotetraploid likely derived by doubling of structurally similar and homologous genomes rather than a hybrid between I. batatas and I. trifida (2x). In addition, sexual polyploidization through fusion of two unreduced gametes from genetically distinct individuals might have been involved in the origin of I. tabascana.

Among the I. trifida complex, I. trifida (6x) had the same number of chromosomes as that of sweetpotato and can easily cross with this cultivated species, therefore considered to be the direct progenitor of sweetpotato( Nishiyama et al. 1961; Nishiyama 1971 ). However, there has been controversy over this view, and different proposals for taxonomical treatment of I. trifida (6x) have been reported, for example, Jones (1967) asserted that I. trifida (6x) was contemporary of I. batatas rather than a different species. Austin (1978) also emphasized that I. trifida (6x) was a sweetpotato and not I. trifida. In this study, same pairing trend was observed between I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas. The six homologous chromosomes paired as a single hexavalent at the majority zygotene-pachytene cells, suggesting considerable homology among the three subgenomes. In addition, a high frequency of bivalent and tetravalent pairing was observed at zygotene-pachytene and metaphase I cells, suggesting closer homology between two of the three subgenomes. The pairing pattern supported previous studies, which concluded that the three parental genomes in sweetpotato were partly homologous, and two of the genomes showed closer homology to one another than to the third based on karyological characteristics and chromosomal pairing at pachytene (Magoon et al.1970), and phylogenetic analyses of COSII genes( Gao et al. ). Gao et al. (2020) further showed that the sweetpotato hexaploid should not be a true type to either an allopolyploid, or to an autopolyploid, but best described by the concept of a segmental allohexaploid. Yang et al. (2017) also showed that the majority of computed phylogenetic trees grouped two haplotypes versus four based on haplotype assembly in the I. batatas genome.

Interestingly, the obvious difference of chromosome pairing trend was observed between I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas. We found that the percentage with a pairing configuration including all homologous chromosomes in I. trifida (6x) was far higher than that in I. batatas at meiotic prophase I and metaphase I cells. Moreover, all six chromosomes were found to align along much of the chromosome lengths in few zygotene cells of I. trifida (6x). This alignment, however, was not observed I. batatas. All these results suggest a higher degree of similarity among three subgenomes in I. trifida (6x) than I. batatas, which effectively distinguishs I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas and rules out the assumption that I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas are the same species (Jones 1967; Austin 1978). Thus, present results tend to support that I. trifida (6x) is an autohexaploid as proposed by Shiotani and Kawase (1989), while sweetpotato is more likely to be a segmental allohexaploid as proposed by Gao et al. (2020).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the present study, we performed cross-species chromosome painting using oligo painting probes developed in I. nil to reveal the genomic structure and the interspecific relationship among three polyploid species of Ipomoea. Our results supported that I. tabascana was an autotetraploid likely derived by doubling of structurally similar and homologous genomes, and ruled out the possibility that I. tabascana was a hybrid between I. batatas and I. trifida. In addition, we also revealed the difference of genome structure between I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas, which ruled out the assumption that I. trifida (6x) and I. batatas were the same species, and supported that I. trifida (6x) was an autohexaploid while I. batatas was a segmental allohexaploid.
